trans-unit.source: Integrating your on-premises identities with Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Integrating your on-premises identities with Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: This is the Azure AD Connect that describes what it is and why you would use it.
trans-unit.target: This is the Azure AD Connect that describes what it is and why you would use it.

trans-unit.source: Building Multi-Factor Authentication into Custom Apps (SDK)
trans-unit.target: Building Multi-Factor Authentication into Custom Apps (SDK)

trans-unit.source: The Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Software Development Kit (SDK) lets you build telephone call and text message verification directly into the sign-in or transaction processes of applications in your Azure AD tenant.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Software Development Kit (SDK) lets you build telephone call and text message verification directly into the sign-in or transaction processes of applications in your Azure AD tenant.

trans-unit.source: The Multi-Factor Authentication SDK is available for C#, Visual Basic (.NET), Java, Perl, PHP and Ruby.
trans-unit.target: The Multi-Factor Authentication SDK is available for C#, Visual Basic (.NET), Java, Perl, PHP and Ruby.

trans-unit.source: The SDK provides a thin wrapper around multi-factor authentication.
trans-unit.target: The SDK provides a thin wrapper around multi-factor authentication.

trans-unit.source: It includes everything you need to write your code, including commented source code files, example files, and a detailed ReadMe file.
trans-unit.target: It includes everything you need to write your code, including commented source code files, example files, and a detailed ReadMe file.

trans-unit.source: Each SDK also includes a certificate and private key for encrypting transactions that is unique to your Multi-Factor Authentication Provider.
trans-unit.target: Each SDK also includes a certificate and private key for encrypting transactions that is unique to your Multi-Factor Authentication Provider.

trans-unit.source: As long as you have a provider, you can download the SDK in as many languages and formats as you need.
trans-unit.target: As long as you have a provider, you can download the SDK in as many languages and formats as you need.

trans-unit.source: The structure of the APIs in the Multi-Factor Authentication SDK is quite simple.
trans-unit.target: The structure of the APIs in the Multi-Factor Authentication SDK is quite simple.

trans-unit.source: You make a single function call to an API with the multi-factor option parameters, such as the verification mode, and user data, such as the telephone number to call or the PIN number to validate.
trans-unit.target: You make a single function call to an API with the multi-factor option parameters, such as the verification mode, and user data, such as the telephone number to call or the PIN number to validate.

trans-unit.source: The APIs translate the function call into web services requests to the cloud-based Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Service.
trans-unit.target: The APIs translate the function call into web services requests to the cloud-based Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Service.

trans-unit.source: All calls must include a reference to the private certificate that is included in every SDK.
trans-unit.target: All calls must include a reference to the private certificate that is included in every SDK.

trans-unit.source: Because the APIs do not have access to users registered in Azure Active Directory, you must provide user information, such as phone numbers and PIN codes, in a file or database.
trans-unit.target: Because the APIs do not have access to users registered in Azure Active Directory, you must provide user information, such as phone numbers and PIN codes, in a file or database.

trans-unit.source: Also, the APIs do not provide enrollment or user management features, so you need to build these processes into your application.
trans-unit.target: Also, the APIs do not provide enrollment or user management features, so you need to build these processes into your application.

trans-unit.source: Download the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication SDK
trans-unit.target: Download the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication SDK

trans-unit.source: There are two different ways that you can download the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication SDK.
trans-unit.target: There are two different ways that you can download the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication SDK.

trans-unit.source: Both are done via the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Both are done via the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: The first is by managing the Multi-Factor Auth Provider directly.
trans-unit.target: The first is by managing the Multi-Factor Auth Provider directly.

trans-unit.source: The second is via the service settings.
trans-unit.target: The second is via the service settings.

trans-unit.source: The second option requires either a Multi-Factor Auth Provider or an Azure AD Premium license.
trans-unit.target: The second option requires either a Multi-Factor Auth Provider or an Azure AD Premium license.

trans-unit.source: To download the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication SDK from the Azure portal
trans-unit.target: To download the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication SDK from the Azure portal

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the Azure Portal as an Administrator.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the Azure Portal as an Administrator.

trans-unit.source: On the left, select Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: On the left, select Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: On the Active Directory page, at the top click Multi-Factor Auth Providers
trans-unit.target: On the Active Directory page, at the top click Multi-Factor Auth Providers

trans-unit.source: At the bottom click Manage
trans-unit.target: At the bottom click Manage

trans-unit.source: This will open a new page.
trans-unit.target: This will open a new page.

trans-unit.source: On the left, at the bottom, click SDK.
trans-unit.target: On the left, at the bottom, click SDK.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><linkText>Download</linkText><html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html><linkText>Download</linkText><html></html>

trans-unit.source: Select the language you want and click on one the associated download links.
trans-unit.target: Select the language you want and click on one the associated download links.

trans-unit.source: Save the download.
trans-unit.target: Save the download.

trans-unit.source: To download the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication SDK via the service settings
trans-unit.target: To download the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication SDK via the service settings

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the Azure Portal as an Administrator.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the Azure Portal as an Administrator.

trans-unit.source: On the left, select Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: On the left, select Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Double click on your instance of Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Double click on your instance of Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: At the top click Configure
trans-unit.target: At the top click Configure

trans-unit.source: Under multi-factor authentication select Manage service settings
trans-unit.target: Under multi-factor authentication select Manage service settings

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Download</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Download</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the services settings page, at the bottom of the screen click Go to the portal.
trans-unit.target: On the services settings page, at the bottom of the screen click Go to the portal.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Download</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Download</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This will open a new page.
trans-unit.target: This will open a new page.

trans-unit.source: On the left, at the bottom, click SDK.
trans-unit.target: On the left, at the bottom, click SDK.

trans-unit.source: Select the language you want and click on one the associated download links.
trans-unit.target: Select the language you want and click on one the associated download links.

trans-unit.source: Save the download.
trans-unit.target: Save the download.

trans-unit.source: Contents of the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication SDK
trans-unit.target: Contents of the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication SDK

trans-unit.source: Inside the SDK you will find the following items:
trans-unit.target: Inside the SDK you will find the following items:

trans-unit.source: README.
trans-unit.target: README.

trans-unit.source: Explains how to use the Multi-Factor Authentication APIs in a new or existing application.
trans-unit.target: Explains how to use the Multi-Factor Authentication APIs in a new or existing application.

trans-unit.source: Source file(s) for Multi-Factor Authentication
trans-unit.target: Source file(s) for Multi-Factor Authentication

trans-unit.source: Client certificate that you use to communicate with the Multi-Factor Authentication service
trans-unit.target: Client certificate that you use to communicate with the Multi-Factor Authentication service

trans-unit.source: Private key for the certificate
trans-unit.target: Private key for the certificate

trans-unit.source: Call results. A list of call result codes.
trans-unit.target: Call results. A list of call result codes.

trans-unit.source: To open this file, use an application with text formatting, such as WordPad.
trans-unit.target: To open this file, use an application with text formatting, such as WordPad.

trans-unit.source: Use the call result codes to test and troubleshoot the implementation of Multi-Factor Authentication in your application.
trans-unit.target: Use the call result codes to test and troubleshoot the implementation of Multi-Factor Authentication in your application.

trans-unit.source: They are not authentication status codes.
trans-unit.target: They are not authentication status codes.

trans-unit.source: Examples. Sample code for a basic working implementation of Multi-Factor Authentication.
trans-unit.target: Examples. Sample code for a basic working implementation of Multi-Factor Authentication.

trans-unit.source: The client certificate is a unique private certificate that was generated especially for you.
trans-unit.target: The client certificate is a unique private certificate that was generated especially for you.

trans-unit.source: Do not share or lose this file.
trans-unit.target: Do not share or lose this file.

trans-unit.source: It’s your key to ensuring the security of your communications with the Multi-Factor Authentication service.
trans-unit.target: It’s your key to ensuring the security of your communications with the Multi-Factor Authentication service.

trans-unit.source: Code Sample: Standard Mode Phone Verification
trans-unit.target: Code Sample: Standard Mode Phone Verification

trans-unit.source: This code sample shows you how to use the APIs in the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication SDK to add standard mode voice call verification to your application.
trans-unit.target: This code sample shows you how to use the APIs in the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication SDK to add standard mode voice call verification to your application.

trans-unit.source: Standard mode is a telephone call that the user responds to by pressing the # key.
trans-unit.target: Standard mode is a telephone call that the user responds to by pressing the # key.

trans-unit.source: This example uses the C# .NET 2.0 Multi-Factor Authentication SDK in a basic ASP.NET application with C# server-side logic, but the process is very similar for simple implementations in other languages.
trans-unit.target: This example uses the C# .NET 2.0 Multi-Factor Authentication SDK in a basic ASP.NET application with C# server-side logic, but the process is very similar for simple implementations in other languages.

trans-unit.source: Because the SDK includes source files, not executable files, you can build the files and reference them or include them directly in your application.
trans-unit.target: Because the SDK includes source files, not executable files, you can build the files and reference them or include them directly in your application.

trans-unit.source: When implementing Multi-Factor Authentication, use the additional factors as secondary or tertiary verification to supplement your primary authentication method.
trans-unit.target: When implementing Multi-Factor Authentication, use the additional factors as secondary or tertiary verification to supplement your primary authentication method.

trans-unit.source: These methods are not designed to be used as primary authentication methods.
trans-unit.target: These methods are not designed to be used as primary authentication methods.

trans-unit.source: Code Sample Overview
trans-unit.target: Code Sample Overview

trans-unit.source: This sample code for a very simple web demo application uses a telephone call with a # key response to complete the user's authentication.
trans-unit.target: This sample code for a very simple web demo application uses a telephone call with a # key response to complete the user's authentication.

trans-unit.source: This telephone call factor is known in Multi-Factor Authentication as standard mode.
trans-unit.target: This telephone call factor is known in Multi-Factor Authentication as standard mode.

trans-unit.source: The client-side code does not include any Multi-Factor Authentication-specific elements.
trans-unit.target: The client-side code does not include any Multi-Factor Authentication-specific elements.

trans-unit.source: Because the additional authentication factors are independent of the primary authentication, you can add them without changing the existing sign-on interface.
trans-unit.target: Because the additional authentication factors are independent of the primary authentication, you can add them without changing the existing sign-on interface.

trans-unit.source: The APIs in the Multi-Factor SDK let you customize the user experience, but you might not need to change anything at all.
trans-unit.target: The APIs in the Multi-Factor SDK let you customize the user experience, but you might not need to change anything at all.

trans-unit.source: The server-side code adds standard-mode authentication in Step 2.
trans-unit.target: The server-side code adds standard-mode authentication in Step 2.

trans-unit.source: It creates a PfAuthParams object with the parameters that are required for standard-mode verification: username, telephone number, and mode, and the path to the client certificate (CertFilePath), which is required in each call.
trans-unit.target: It creates a PfAuthParams object with the parameters that are required for standard-mode verification: username, telephone number, and mode, and the path to the client certificate (CertFilePath), which is required in each call.

trans-unit.source: For a demonstration of all parameters in PfAuthParams, see the Example file in the SDK.
trans-unit.target: For a demonstration of all parameters in PfAuthParams, see the Example file in the SDK.

trans-unit.source: Next, the code passes the PfAuthParams object to the pf_authenticate() function.
trans-unit.target: Next, the code passes the PfAuthParams object to the pf_authenticate() function.

trans-unit.source: The return value indicates the success or failure of the authentication.
trans-unit.target: The return value indicates the success or failure of the authentication.

trans-unit.source: The out parameters, callStatus and errorID, contain additional call result information.
trans-unit.target: The out parameters, callStatus and errorID, contain additional call result information.

trans-unit.source: The call result codes are documented in the call results file in the SDK.
trans-unit.target: The call result codes are documented in the call results file in the SDK.

trans-unit.source: This minimal implementation can be written in a just a few lines.
trans-unit.target: This minimal implementation can be written in a just a few lines.

trans-unit.source: However, in production code, you would include more sophisticated error handling, additional database code, and an enhanced user experience.
trans-unit.target: However, in production code, you would include more sophisticated error handling, additional database code, and an enhanced user experience.

trans-unit.source: Web Client Code
trans-unit.target: Web Client Code

trans-unit.source: The following is web client code for a demo page.
trans-unit.target: The following is web client code for a demo page.

trans-unit.source: Server-Side Code
trans-unit.target: Server-Side Code

trans-unit.source: In the following server-side code, Multi-Factor Authentication is configured and run in Step 2.
trans-unit.target: In the following server-side code, Multi-Factor Authentication is configured and run in Step 2.

trans-unit.source: Standard mode (MODE_STANDARD) is a telephone call to which the user responds by pressing the # key.
trans-unit.target: Standard mode (MODE_STANDARD) is a telephone call to which the user responds by pressing the # key.
